facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1964 of the Patna High Court in M.J.C. No. 498 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1964 of the Patna High Court in M.J.C. No. 498 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal on a certificate granted by the Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: C. Ghosh and K. K. Sinha, for the appellant. Mustafi and A. K. Nag, for respondent No. 3 K. Chatterjee, for respondent No. 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, C. J.-This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Patna High Court

facts.text: Appellant Jagdish Pandey joined as a lecturer in Ramakrishna College Madhubani in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and arises in the following circumstances. The appellant. Jagdish Pandey, joined as a lecturer in Ramakrishna College Madhubani in July 1948.

facts.text: Appointment approved by the University in June 1949.

anchor.surface_text: His appointment was approved by the University in June 1949, and on September 23, 1951 he was companyfirmed as a lecturer in that College.

facts.text: Appellant confirmed as lecturer on September 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: His appointment was approved by the University in June 1949, and on September 23, 1951 he was companyfirmed as a lecturer in that College. In July 1961 the post of the Principal of Pandaul College, Pandaul fell vacant and was advertised.

facts.text: Post of Principal of Pandaul College fell vacant in July 1961 and was advertised.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1961 the post of the Principal of Pandaul College, Pandaul fell vacant and was advertised. The appellant was one of the applicants and was appointed after interview as the Principal of the companylege on January 22, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant appointed Principal of Pandaul College on January 22, 1962 after interview.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was one of the applicants and was appointed after interview as the Principal of the companylege on January 22, 1962. On January 24, 1962, the appellants appointment as Principal of the College was approved by the University.

facts.text: Appointment as Principal approved by University on January 24, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On January 24, 1962, the appellants appointment as Principal of the College was approved by the University. It appears that the appointment was challenged by a writ petition before the Patna Court, but that challenge failed on July 11, 1962, when the petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Appointment challenged by writ petition before Patna High Court, dismissed on July 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appointment was challenged by a writ petition before the Patna Court, but that challenge failed on July 11, 1962, when the petition was dismissed. In the meantime, the Bihar Legislature passed the Bihar State Universities  University of Bihar, Bhagalpur and, Ranchi   Amendment  Act, No. 13 of 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Act  which came into force on April 21, 1962.

facts.text: Bihar State Universities Amendment Act, No. 13 of 1962 came into force on April 21, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Bihar Legislature passed the Bihar State Universities  University of Bihar, Bhagalpur and, Ranchi   Amendment  Act, No. 13 of 1962  hereinafter referred to as the Act  which came into force on April 21, 1962. Section 4 thereof was in the following terms- Certain appointments, etc., of teachers of numberGovernment affiliated companyleges to be subject to Chancellors orders-Notwithstanding anything companytained in the said Act or the Magadh University Act, 1961  Bihar Act IV of 1962  or the statutes made thereunder,

facts.text: Section 4 of the Act makes appointments of teachers between November 27, 1961 and March 1, 1962 subject to Chancellor's orders on recommendation of University Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 thereof was in the following terms- Certain appointments, etc., of teachers of numberGovernment affiliated companyleges to be subject to Chancellors orders-Notwithstanding anything companytained in the said Act or the Magadh University Act, 1961  Bihar Act IV of 1962  or the statutes made thereunder, or the Bihar State Universities  University of Bihar, Bhagalpur and Ranchi  Ordinance, 1962,  Bihar Ordinance No. 1 of 1962  every appointment, dismissal, removal, termination of service or reduction in rank of any teacher of a companylege, number belonging to the State Government, affiliated to the University established under the said Act or the Magadh University Act, 1961  Bihar Act IV of 1962  made on or after the twenty-seventh day of November, 1961 and before the first day of March, 1962, shall be subject to such order as the Chancellor of the University may, on the recommendation of the University Service Commission established under section 48A of the said Act, pass with respect thereto.

facts.text: Chancellor approved appellant's appointment till November 30, 1962 or till candidate recommended by Commission joined, by order dated August 18, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into force, the appellant received an order dated August 18, 1962 from the Chancellor of the University to the effect that the Chancellor had been pleased to approve, under s. 4 of the Act, on the recommendation of the Commission the appointment of the appellant as Principal of the Pandaul College till November 30, 1962 or till the candidate recommended by the Commission joined, whichever was earlier.

facts.text: Similar order passed for another teacher of Ramakrishna College on May 31, 1962, challenged and struck down on April 23, 1963 by Patna High Court for violating natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that before this, a similar order had been passed with respect to another teacher of Ramakrishna College Madhubani on May 31, 1962, and that order was challenged in the Patna High Court on the ground that the teacher in question had number been heard before the order was made and therefore the order was bad as it violated the principles of natural justice. That case was decided by the High Court on April 23, 1963 and the order in question was struck down on the ground that it violated principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Commission issued notice to appellant on November 8, 1962 to show cause why Commission should not recommend modification of August 18, 1962 order.

anchor.surface_text: it was realised sometime in October or Novem- ber, 1962 that the order of August 18, 1962 in the case of the appellant might be similarly challenged so on November 8, 1962 the Commission gave numberice to the appellant to show cause why the Commission should number recommend to the Chancellor that there was numberadequate justification or reason for the Chancellor to modify the order already passed on August 18, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant replied to the notice and controverted all grounds.

anchor.surface_text: However, the appellant replied to the numberice and companytroverted all the grounds mentioned therein, though it number appears from the final order which was passed on February 18, 1963 that the only ground that companycerned him was that he was number academically qualified for appointment as Principal of the College on the date of the selection by the governing body.

facts.text: Appellant given hearing by Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant seems to have been given a hearing by the Commission and eventually on February 18, 1963 the Chancellor passed another order which purported to modify the order of August 18, 1962 insofar as it related to the appellant.

facts.text: Chancellor passed order on February 18, 1963 modifying August 18 order: give appellant year or two to obtain second class Masters Degree, otherwise terminate services.

anchor.surface_text: The modification was that the appellant would be given a year or two to appear at the examination to enable him to obtain a second class Masters Degree-, otherwise his services would be terminated. Thereupon the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging both the orders of August 18, 1962 and February 18, 1963.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Patna High Court challenging orders of August 18, 1962 and February 18, 1963; dismissed by High Court on April 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging both the orders of August 18, 1962 and February 18, 1963. ... The High Court rejected all the three companytentions and dismissed the petition, but granted a certificate to appeal to this Court

facts.text: Appellant had third class Masters degree.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that the appellant had a third class Masters degree and therefore did number satisfy the qualification that a Principal should have a second class Masters degree.

facts.text: Appellant had ten years teaching experience in a college of which seven years in degree college; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed, that the appellant had ten years teaching experience in a companylege of which sever,, years were in a degree companylege.

facts.text: Minimum qualification for Principal per Chapter 16 Rule 1: second class Masters degree and at least ten years teaching experience etc.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that according to chapter 16, r.  1  of the Statutes, the minimum qualification for the appointment of Principal is a second class Masters degree and at least ten years,, A.I.R. 1964 Patna, 41. teaching experience in a companylege of which at least seven years must be in a degree companylege or five years experience as Principal of an Intermediate College.

facts.text: Sub-rule 6 of Rule 1 Chapter 16: qualifications of teacher confirmed before July 1, 1952 deemed equivalent to minimum for post held.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relies on sub-r.  6  of r.  1  which is in these terms Notwithstanding anything in the Article, the qualifications of a teacher already in service and companyfirmed before the 1st July 1952 shall be companysidered to be equivalent to the minimum qualifications for the post he holds.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that sub-r.6 deems appellant to have second class Masters degree for Principal post.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the order dated February 18, 1963 passed by the Chancellor requiring the governing body of the Pandaul College to give the appellant a year or two to appear at an examination to enable him to obtain a second class Masters degree, otherwise his services might be terminated, is number valid, for the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification of a second class Masters degree by virtue of sub-rule  6  of the Statutes

facts.text: Report of Joint Select Committee made on November 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: but the report of the Joint Select Committee, which resulted in the enactment of s. 48-A, was made on November 27, 1961.

facts.text: Section 48-A came into force on March 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This section came into force on March 1, 1962

Section 4 thereof was in the following terms- Certain appointments, etc., of teachers of numberGovernment affiliated companyleges to be subject to Chancellors orders-Notwithstanding anything companytained in the said Act or the Magadh University Act, 1961  Bihar Act IV of 1962  or the statutes made thereunder,

concepts.interpretation: Power of Chancellor limited to scrutinising appointments etc. between specified dates for compliance with University Act, Statutes etc. in substance and procedure; Commission must hear teacher before recommending per natural justice principles.

anchor.surface_text: s. 4 of the Act was ultra vires, as it violated Art. 14 of the Constitution. Secondly, it was urged that the order of August 18, 1962 violated the principles of natural justice

concepts.interpretation: Section 4 upheld as not discriminatory after reading down; dates not arbitrary as class of appointments between Nov 27, 1961 and Mar 1, 1962 has rational nexus to object of preventing irregularities before Commission establishment.

anchor.surface_text: and that order was challenged in the Patna High Court on the ground that the teacher in question had number been heard before the order was made and therefore the order was bad as it violated the principles of natural justice.

concepts.interpretation: Hearing required before Commission recommends to Chancellor under s.4; initial order without hearing invalid but cured by subsequent notice and hearing; treated as fresh order.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that s. 4 must be read down and if we read it down there is numberreason to hold that the legislature was companyferring a naked arbitrary power on the Chancellor.

concepts.interpretation: s.4 read down to limit Chancellor's power to scrutiny for legality under University laws and imply natural justice hearing by Commission.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that if the dates are arbitrary, s. 4 would be violative of Art. 14, for then there would be numberjustification for singling out a class of teachers who were appointed or dismissed etc.

concepts.interpretation: Dates in s.4 form valid class with rational nexus to preventing irregularities in appointments before s.48A enforcement.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging both the orders of August 18, 1962 and February 18, 1963.

issues.text: Whether s. 4 of the Act was ultra vires, as it violated Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: s. 4 of the Act was ultra vires, as it violated Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the order of August 18, 1962 violated the principles of natural justice and could not be modified after November 30, 1962 as it had worked itself out, there was no power of review under s. 4, and proceedings based on November 8 notice were mala fide
Whether in view of ch. 16 r. 1 of the Statutes, the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification for Principal and the order of February 18, 1963 was bad

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was urged that in view of ch. 16 r. 1 of the Statutes of the University, the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification for the post of the Principal and therefore the order of February 18, 1963 requiring him to appear at an examination to obtain a Second Class Masters degree or in the alternative requiring that his services be terminated was bad.

issues.text: Whether the dates mentioned in s. 4 were completely arbitrary violating Art. 14
Whether s. 4 confers uncanalised powers on the Chancellor without any criterion

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that s. 4 must be read down and if we read it down there is no reason to hold that the legislature was conferring a naked arbitrary power on the Chancellor.

issues.text: Whether s. 4 makes provision for hearing the teacher before passing order, per natural justice
Whether s. 4 is discriminatory for not providing University approval unlike s. 48-A(6)

arguments.claim: s. 4 of the Act was ultra vires, as it violated Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: s. 4 of the Act was ultra vires, as it violated Art. 14 of the Constitution. Secondly, it was urged that the order of August 18, 1962 violated the principles of natural justice

arguments.court_reasoning: s.4 read down to limit Chancellor's power to scrutiny for compliance with University laws and imply natural justice; dates form valid class with rational nexus

arguments.claim: dates mentioned in s. 4 were completely arbitrary and therefore there was no valid classification to uphold the validity of the section
arguments.court_reasoning: Dates from Nov 27 1961 (Joint Committee report) to Mar 1 1962 (s48A enforcement) have nexus to preventing irregularities in anticipation of Commission

arguments.claim: s. 4 confers uncanalised powers on the Chancellor without indicating any criterion
arguments.court_reasoning: Read down s.4 to limit to scrutiny for compliance with University Act/Statutes in substance/procedure; not naked power

arguments.claim: no provision was made in s. 4 for hearing of the teacher before passing an order thereunder
arguments.court_reasoning: Implicit that Commission hears teacher before recommending per natural justice; s.4 read to include this

arguments.claim: s. 4 does not provide for approval by the University of the Chancellor's order while s. 48-A(6) does, and it is therefore discriminatory
arguments.court_reasoning: s.4 addresses specific situation pre-Commission; University approval out of place

arguments.claim: order of August 18, 1962 violated the principles of natural justice and it could not be modified after November 30, 1962 as it had worked itself out and there was no power of review given to the Chancellor under s. 4 and further that proceedings based on the notice issued on November 8, 1962 by the Commission were a mala fide device
arguments.court_reasoning: Initial order invalid without hearing but cured by notice/hearing; treat Feb 18 as fresh order; Aug 18 fell upon subsequent proceedings

arguments.claim: in view of ch. 16 r. 1 of the Statutes of the University, the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification for the post of the Principal and therefore the order of February 18, 1963 ... was bad

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was urged that in view of ch. 16 r. 1 of the Statutes of the University, the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification for the post of the Principal and therefore the order of February 18, 1963 requiring him to appear at an examination

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e companysidered to be equal to the minimum qualification required for the post of the Principal, even though in either of these cases the actual qual

arguments.court_reasoning: sub-r.6 deems pre-1952 confirmed teachers' qualifications equivalent to minimum for post held, permanently for promotions/appointments

arguments.claim: s. 4 must be read down ... intention ... that all appointments ... should be scrutinised ... in accordance with the University Act and the Statutes ... both in the matter of qualifications, and in the matter of procedure
the Commission before making the recommendation would hear the teacher concerned, according to the rules of natural justice. This ... is implicit in the section

sub-r. 6 ... says in effect that whatever may be the actual qualification of the teacher appointed and confirmed before July 1, 1952 that qualification will be considered to be equal to the minimum qualification for the post he holds ... must enure ... for all time in future for the purpose of promotion or appointment

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relies on sub-r. 6 of r. 1 which is in these terms Notwithstanding anything in the Article, the qualifications of a teacher already in service and confirmed before the 1st July 1952 shall be considered to be equivalent to the minimum qualifications

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e companysidered to be equal to the minimum qualification required for the post of the Principal, even though in either of these cases the actual qual

arguments.court_reasoning: Deeming provision protects pre-1952 teachers permanently; words 'post he holds' descriptive, not limiting

arguments.claim: teachers appointed etc. between these two dates did not form a class that would have nexus with the object to be achieved
arguments.court_reasoning: Object: check irregularities post-Joint Committee report pre-s48A; rational classification under Art14

arguments.claim: order of February 18, 1963 ... must be treated to be a fresh order and as it is not defective on the ground that the principles of natural justice had been violated
arguments.court_reasoning: Subsequent hearing cures initial defect; treat as fresh proceedings

holdings.text: s. 4 cannot be struck down on the ground that it has fixed two arbitrary dates and has visited teachers appointed, dismissed etc. between these two dates with a differential treatment as compared to teachers appointed before November 27, 1961.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dates from Joint Select Committee report (Nov 27, 1961) to s.48A enforcement (Mar 1, 1962) form class with rational nexus to preventing irregularities in anticipation of Commission establishment.

holdings.text: s. 4 must be read down ... it only authorises the Chancellor to scrutinise appointments, dismissals etc. made between these two dates for the purpose of satisfying himself that these appointments, dismissals etc., were in accordance with the University Act and the Statutes, Ordinances, Regulations or Rules made thereunder, both as to the substantive and procedural aspects thereof.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading gives uncanalised power but purposive interpretation limits to scrutiny for compliance with University laws to avoid arbitrariness under Art.14.

holdings.text: the Commission before making the recommendation would hear the teacher concerned, according to the rules of natural justice. This ... is implicit in the section.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 requires Chancellor's order on Commission's recommendation; natural justice implicitly mandates hearing by Commission before recommendation.

holdings.text: s. 4 was enacted, to meet a particular situation as we have already indicated above, and in that situation the approval by the University of the Chancellors order would be quite out of place. Section 4 cannot be struck down as discriminatory on this ground.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 addresses transient pre-Commission irregularities; University approval unnecessary unlike ongoing s.48A(6) regime; no discrimination.

holdings.text: We therefore read s. 4 in the manner indicated above both as to the limit of the Chancellors power while passing an order thereunder and as to the necessity of the Commission giving a hearing ... and so read we are of opinion that s. 4 cannot be held to be discriminatory and as such liable to be struck down under Art. 14 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining reading down for limited scrutiny and implicit hearing requirement upholds s.4 against Art.14 challenge.

holdings.text: The order made on February 18, 1963 therefore cannot be said to suffer from the defect that it was passed without observing the principles of natural justice. As for the order of August 18, 1962, it must be taken to have fallen when action was taken to give notice to the appellant on November 8, 1962 and pass a fresh order on February 18, 1963 after giving a proper hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The order made on February 18, 1963 therefore cannot be said to suffer from the defect that it was passed without observing the principles of na- tural justice. As for the order of August 18, 1962, it must be taken to have fallen

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subsequent notice and hearing cure initial lack of hearing; treat Feb order as fresh under s.4; Aug order lapsed upon fresh proceedings.

holdings.text: the order dated February 18, 1963 passed by the Chancellor requiring the governing body of the Pandaul College to give the appellant a year or two to appear at an examination to enable him to obtain a second class Masters degree, otherwise his services might be terminated, is not valid, for the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification of a second class Masters degree by virtue of sub-rule 6 of the Statutes.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the order dated February 18, 1963 passed by the Chancellor requiring the governing body of the Pandaul College to give the appellant a year or two to appear at an examination to enable him to obtain a second class Masters degree, otherwise his services might be terminated, is number valid, for the appellant must be deemed to have the minimum qualification of a second class Masters degree by virtue of sub-rule  6  of the Statutes

holdings.reasoning_summary: sub-r.6 deeming provision permanently equates pre-1952 confirmed teachers' actual qualifications to minimum for 'the post he holds'; applies to promotions as protective and prospective; 'post he holds' descriptive not limitative.
